clinical_study.brief_title: FM Systems on Children With Auditory Processing Disorders
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Frequency Modulation (FM) Assistive Listening Device Systems on Listening and Related Skills in Children With Auditory Processing Disorders (APD)

brief_summary.textblock:
Auditory Processing Disorder (APD) is a disorder where the functions of the ear (outer, middle, inner) are normal but the person has difficulty identifying or discriminating sounds (Dawes & Bishop, 2009) and experiences listening difficulties in noise. Personal Frequency Modulation (FM) systems are wireless listening devices that pick up the speaker's voice and transmit it to a receiver in the listener's ear. In this way, the negative effects of ambient noise, distance from speaker and reverberation are reduced (Keith & Purdy, 2014).
The principal research question is whether FM systems improve auditory attention, listening in noise performance and listening in spatialised noise in children with Auditory Processing Disorder (APD) in relation to just auditory training alone. We hypothesize that the FM system will lead to improved attention scores, improved speech in noise perception (aided and unaided) and improved ability to listen in spatialised noise that after prolonged FM use (6 months). Additionally, we hypothesise that these results will correlate with questionnaires (filled out by parents, teachers and children).
Thirty (30) children with a diagnosis of an APD from the Great Ormond Street Hospital Audiology clinic will be recruited. The children need to fulfil the following criteria:
1. Diagnosis of APD (based on routine clinical tests at GOSH):
1. Abnormal performance on the auditory figure ground test (a speech in noise test) of the SCAN-C (i.e. at the 1st percentile score as per UK norms), or in the High-Cue or Low-Cue score of the LiSN-S test and
2. Abnormal performance in one non-speech auditory processing test (frequency pattern, duration pattern, gaps in noise or random gap detection pattern tasks), and
3. Parent reported speech in noise and other listening difficulties.
2. No neurological disorder, pervasive or attention deficit disorder or developmental delay.
3. Normal IQ.
4. Age range 8-11 years.

detailed_description.textblock:
Background and justification of the study Auditory Processing Disorder Auditory Processing Disorder (APD) is a disorder where the functions of the ear (outer, middle, inner) are normal but the person has difficulty identifying or discriminating sounds (Dawes & Bishop, 2009). For children with APD it is particularly difficult to hear when the listening conditions are not ideal. For example, when there is background noise it becomes really challenging to focus on the speaker. Two other factors that influence their hearing ability are reverberation and the distance from the speaker (Keith & Purdy, 2014).
Moreover, there are studies which show comorbidity of APD with language and reading disorders (Sharma et al., 2009) and it is supported that attention and memory might influence APD (Moore et al., 2013). It is also argued that APD could just as well be one dimension in a cluster of developmental conditions (Dawes & Bishop, 2009). Nonetheless, the profile of a child with APD should be clearly outlined in order not to be confused with other common developmental disorders (Bamiou et al., 2001).
FM systems Personal Frequency Modulation (FM) systems are wireless listening devices that pick up the speaker's voice and transmit it to a receiver in the listener's ear. In this way, the negative effects of ambient noise, distance from speaker and reverberation are reduced (Keith & Purdy, 2014).
Research suggests that children with APD after a prolonged use of FM systems benefit from improved speech perception which is possibly linked to an enhanced auditory system (Johnston et al., 2009). Adding to that, children with APD have shown improved speech in noise perception when using the FM system, hence emphasizing the advantages of an FM system in discriminating speech in background noise (Johnston et al., 2009).
There are not many studies, though, that focus on the use of FM systems on children with APD. Attention and ability to listen in spatialised noise in children with APD after the use of an FM system has not been researched yet. As the central point of this study will be the use of the FM system by children with APD for 6 months, it is expected that the findings could add valuable information on the subject. In addition, possible benefits of the FM system will be examined in detail. More particularly, possible improvements in auditory attention, speech in noise performance (aided and unaided) and listening in spatialised noise will be looked into.
Attention Higher-level brain functions (neurocognitive and behavioural) have a major influence on the abilities of the listener to decode and interpret the received sounds (Bellis, 2011). Attention, in turn, has a central role in shaping the perception of complex auditory tasks (Sussman & Steinschneider, 2009). Attention plays an important part in "reorganizing passive, low-level acoustic processes during normal development" (Sussman & Steinschneider, 2009: 784). Thus, for children with APD, attention deficits can have a negative impact on automatic sound organization (Sussman & Steinschneider, 2009). In his review, Moore (2011) highlights that poor listening does not mean that children's hearing is bad. Rather, results of his studies have suggested that most listening problems are caused by poor attention or working memory. Thus, if no other neurological symptoms exist, then poor listening is most likely linked with attention and memory deficits (Moore, 2011). However, Sharma et al. (2009) conclude from their study that auditory attention and memory do not necessarily present together with APD.
This study will use the Test of Everyday Attention for Children (TEACh) to test children's auditory attention. Another test will be administered to assess children's ability to listen is spatialised noise is the Listen in Spatialised Noise - Sentences test (LiSN-S). Besides, a speech in noise test will be performed in the classroom (with and without the use of the FM systems). Therefore, possible links between APD and auditory attention and listening in spatialised noise abilities will be identified. This will build on the current knowledge on the matter and will help us determine a possible link between FM use and attention performance. As stated earlier, this cognitive function has not been tested for in previous studies which employed FM use on APD population.
Listening in noise As already mentioned, APD usually coincides with poor speech in noise perception (Keith & Purdy, 2014). Interestingly enough findings from the study of Ferguson et al. (2011) indicate that children with APD did not have a difficulty listening in noise. Nevertheless, the evidence on this claim is not enough (British Society of Audiology, 2011a). In fact, Johnston et al.'s (2009) study indicates improvements in listening in speech noise performance in children with APD, following a 5-month personal FM system intervention. In our present study, two tests that assess speech in noise perception will be administered; the LiSN-S test, which assesses listening performance in spatialised speech noise and the Chear Auditory Perception Test (CAPT), which will be administered in the classroom (with and without the use of FM) (Vickers et al., 2013) Results might reveal possible links between APD and listening in noise performance and thus could shed more light on the issue raised by Ferguson et al.'s study.
Aim and hypotheses
Principal research questions:
The principal research question is to examine the effects that FM systems have on auditory attention and listening in noise performance in children with Auditory Processing Disorder (APD). More specifically, we hypothesize that the prolonged use of the personal FM system will lead to improved auditory attention, improved ability to listen in spatialised noise and improved listening in noise perception (aided and unaided) and that these improvements will be correlated with the questionnaire responses from parents, teachers and children..
Hypotheses:
i. Children with APD who use the FM system will show greater improvements in auditory attention, listening in spatialised speech noise and listening in noise (aided and unaided) after 6 months of FM use in comparison to the APD control group.
ii. Children with APD who use the FM system will show greater improvements in listening in spatialised speech noise after 6 months of FM use in comparison to the APD control group.
iii. Children with APD who use the FM system will show greater improvements in listening in noise (aided and unaided) after 6 months of FM use in comparison to the APD control group.
iv. All the above outcome measures (auditory attention, listening in spatialised noise, listening in noise) will correlate with questionnaire results from the parents (asked about their child's improvement), questionnaire results from teachers (reporting on the attention of their student) and questionnaire results from the child reporting on their listening and hearing aid benefit.
Secondary research questions:
- Is listening in noise (aided) similar with listening in noise (unaided) after 6 months of FM use?
- What are the characteristics of children with no improvement/lower rates of improvement?
Summary of main issues Research suggests that children with APD after a prolonged use of FM systems benefit from improved speech perception which is possibly linked to an enhanced auditory system (Johnston et al., 2009).. Adding to that, children with APD have shown improved speech in noise perception when using the FM system (in an uncontrolled study); hence emphasizing the advantages of an FM system in discriminating speech in background noise (Johnston et al., 2009). There are not many studies, though, that focus on the use of FM systems on children with APD.
This study will assess the effects of FM listening assistive devices use on a range of outcome measures. As the central point of this study will be the use of the FM system by children with APD for 6 months, it is expected that the findings could add valuable information on the matter. In addition, possible benefits of the FM system will be examined in detail. More particularly, possible improvements in auditory attention, listening in spatialised noise and speech in noise discrimination (aided and unaided) will be looked into.
Intervention ethical issues:
We will split the children with APD into (a) children who will only receive the FM system , (b) children who will not receive any intervention for the study period (this group will receive the FM system after we complete the study, at 6 months under these conditions: A. They show no improvement or decreased scores in their listening-in-noise scores, and B. The recommendations by the APD clinic at GOSH include FM system as management strategies. For instance, if a child shows decreased scores in their listening-in-noise scores, we look at the recommendations and if it suggested that they use FM system in classroom, then we will provide the FM system to the child. On the other hand, if a child shows improved scores in the listening-in-noise scores, then they will not require to get any form of intervention at the end of the study as they exhibited improvements anyway).
Currently from an audit conducted at GOSH APD Clinic, only 1 in 3 children who are recommended to have an FM system obtain this by school funding (or by their parents funding the device) and this takes place several months after the recommendation has been made. Therefore, provision of this device is not standard practice. As such the FM systems are issued as part of this research study.
We believe that the FM system will be of benefit to all children who will be recruited and will be provided to all recruited children but with a delay of 6 months for the third group of children due to the need for a non-intervention control group for the study period. An inclusion of a control, no intervention group, is essential for any Randomised Control Trial.
Outcome measures issues:
This study will use the following outcome measures for the intervention.
Primary outcome measure:
1. A validated attention test (Test of Everyday Attention for Children -TEACh) to test children's auditory attention.
2. A validated test on Listening in Spatialised Noise - Sentences test (LiSN-S). This tests children's ability to listen through spatialised speech noise.
3. A validated consonant perception test called Chear Auditory Perception Test (CAPT). This tests children's ability to discriminate words through background noise.
Secondary outcome measures:
1. Parental questionnaires (The Children's Communication Checklist-2 [CCC-2] and the Children's Auditory Performance Scale (CHAPS).
2. Teacher questionnaire (Screening Instrument For Targeting Educational Risk [SIFTER]).
3. Children questionnaires (Listening Inventory For Education-Revised [LIFE-R] and the Abbreviated Profile of Hearing Aid Benefit [APHAB]).
There is still not a universal APD test battery (British Society of Audiology, 2011b). The comparison of the results from the four groups will help assess whether there are any changes in auditory attention and listening in noise performance (aided and unaided) and whether changes correlate with the results from the questionnaires.
Inclusion criteria:
As previously stated the inclusion criteria of the study are (a) APD diagnosis, (b) Age range 8-11 years (c) Normal IQ, and (d) No neurological problems. Exclusion criteria are: (i) Presence of developmental delay, pervasive learning disorder such as autism or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder or non-verbal IQ worse than 85. (ii) Presence of neurological disorder such as epilepsy.
Criterion (b) is used as this is the main age of referrals for APD testing at GOSH. Criteria (c), (d), (i) and (ii) are set out in order to minimize the possibility that APD is caused by other cognitive or neurological problems or is linked to other pervasive learning disorders and developmental delays.
School and teacher involvement:
The teachers of the children who receive the FM systems will be provided with a PIS and consent form and will be required to wear the FM microphone (which picks up the teacher's voice and transmits it wirelessly to the ear receivers in the child's ear) on their clothes for the duration of the class. Please note that FM systems are provided (funded by the school budget) to some children after clinical recommendations and this is not an unusual situation within the school environment.
We will liaise with the teacher as well as the Special Educational Needs Co-ordinator (SENCO) of the school in order to ensure that the school will be aware that the student has been issued with the FM system. A general guide for FMs (see attached documents, revised) will be made available in addition to information conveyed by the Research Fellow (PhD student) who will visit the school once per term.
In addition, there will be a visit at the beginning and the end of the study (at 0 and 6 months), where the CAPT test will be administered. There has already been a study on this for children with Cochlear Implants which showed that all children in the study were able to use the personal handsets with no issues (Vickers et al., 2013). All children in the classroom will take part, thus informed consent will be sought from their parents. The purpose of including the other children in the classroom is to assess the performance of the APD child in the classroom in relation to his/ her classmates. If some parents do not wish their children take part then we will not include them in this test. This will not hinder our data collection, as our main focus is the APD child, while the number of his/ her non-APD classmates could vary.
Informed consent:
The child's parents will be given detailed written information and consent forms to sign about taking part in the study. They will be given up to a week to study and decide whether they wish for their child to participate in the study. They will only be allowed to take part once they have understood the purpose and procedures of the study and they have signed the consent forms. In addition, children will also be given information sheets adjusted to their age. Written assent from the children in the presence of their parents or carers will be sought.
Rights to withdraw from the study:
This will be outlined on both the information sheet and consent form, and explained verbally throughout. This information will state that participants will be allowed to withdraw from the study at any point should they wish to do so. Withdrawal from the study will not involve any penalty or loss of benefit to them -this information is clearly underlined at the information sheet and will be made clear to them verbally.
Data protection:
The parents of the participant and the participant will be informed that their information will be anonymised and kept confidential. Data will be anonymised prior to analysis by the use of participant codes. Storage of the data will be within a secure password protected database and locked filing unit within UCL, in accordance with the data protection act 1998. If withdrawals take place the participants' data will be deleted.
Other issues:
The consonant discrimination test will be performed on all APD children in the study and also on non-APD children. The results of the two groups will be compared. In order to facilitate the recruitment of the non-APD controls, it will be asked of children with APD to bring one of their friends on the day of that test. These children will be aged and gender matched. However, it is expected that being friends with the study's participants, could be a confounding factor. It could also be that children with APD may not want or may not have a friend to bring with them. In such cases it is asked of parents and children to inform the researchers to be prepared for a lower attendance of non-APD controls. This will also have an impact on the results, as it will reduce the non-APD control group. However, the rationale behind this test is that children with APD will also act as their own controls. The test will be performed once with the FM system on and once with the FM system off. Thus, the efficacy of the FM system can be measured through this comparison. The inclusion of non-APD controls is to have an additional comparison of how well children with APD performed with the FM system compared to age matched controls. It is this comparison that might be compromised due to a reduced control group.
Research Design and Methodology Participants and Recruitment We will recruit 30 children, 8-11 years old. All children will have been diagnosed and referred from the Auditory Processing Disorders Clinic at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH). The total sample size is decided using this power sample: 15 children per group (on a basis of estimated 1 SD effect size, n = 15/f2 where n = sample size per group, f=effect size, 80% power at 5% significance).
The inclusion criteria are:
1. Diagnosis of APD (based on routine clinical tests at GOSH:
a) Abnormal performance on the auditory figure ground test (a speech in noise test) of the SCAN-C (i.e. at the 1st percentile score as per UK norms), and d) Abnormal performance in one non-speech auditory processing test (frequency pattern, duration pattern, gaps in noise or random gap detection pattern tasks), and e) Parent reported speech in noise and other listening difficulties.
2. No neurological disorder, pervasive or attention deficit disorder or developmental delay.
3. Normal IQ.
4. Age range 8-11 years.
Exclusion criteria are:
A. Presence of developmental delay, pervasive learning disorder such as autism or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder or non-verbal IQ worse than 85.
B. Presence of neurological disorder such as epilepsy Subjects will be semi-randomly assigned to each of four intervention arms. The four groups will be stratified for age and balanced for sex.
A prospective case control study will be used. Children will be given an FM system to use at school plus auditory training (in three different intervention groups) and these groups will be directly compared to each other and also compared to the control (no intervention) group. Each child will be enrolled in the study for 6 months. All groups will be tested before the start of the FM intervention and at the end of the study (after 6 months of use of the interventions).
Following are the assessments to be performed for both groups at UCL Ear Institute (detailed explanation of these tests is given later):
- Baseline (before recruitment, 0 months into the study):
- Pure Audiometry Test (PTA)
- Listening in Spatialised noise (LiSN-S)
- Speech in noise tests (aided and unaided)
- Questionnaires (CHAPS, CCC-2)
- Questionnaires (SIFTER, LIFE-R, APHAB)
- Attention test (TEACh)
- Non-verbal IQ test (Weschler test of Non-verbal intelligence)
- At 3 months
- Listening in Spatialised noise (LiSN-S)
- Questionnaires (CHAPS, CCC-2)
- Questionnaires (SIFTER, LIFE-R, APHAB)
- Attention test (TEACh)
- At the end of the study (6 months later):
- Listening in Spatialised Noise (LiSN-S)
- Questionnaires (CHAPS, CCC-2)
- Questionnaires (SIFTER, LIFE-R, APHAB)
- Attention test (TEACh).
Explanation of each test:
1. A hearing test (Pure Tone Audiometry approx. 10mins). To determine their hearing is normal.
2. An attention test. The Test of Everyday Attention for Children (TEACh). To be conducted as play type activities by the PhD student after receiving sufficient training by the clinical psychologist. (approx. 45mins possibly cut down to 30mins). To assess their attention.
3. Listening in spatialised noise test (LiSN-S, approx. 15mins). To be administered through the use of headphones by the PhD student. To determine their listening in spatialised speech noise abilities.
4. Consonant perception test in noise called Chear Auditory Perception Test (CAPT, approx. 45mins). This tests children's ability to discriminate words through background noise. This test will be performed on all APD children in the study and their results will be compared results from non-APD children.
5. Two questionnaires to be filled by the children's parents.
1. The Children's Communication Checklist-2 (CCC-2). A 70-item questionnaire which screens for communication problems (including language disorders and autism).
2. The Children's Auditory Performance Scale (CHAPS). It assesses aspects of children's listening.
6. One questionnaire to be completed by the teachers (Screening Instrument For Targeting Educational Risk [SIFTER]) to assess their attention, communication, class participation and school behaviour.
7. Two questionnaires to be completed by the children (Listening Inventory For Education-Revised [LIFE-R] for assessing their listening difficulty and Abbreviated Profile of Hearing Aid Benefit for assessing the benefit of the FM use by the FM group).
8. Non-verbal IQ test (Weschler test of non-verbal intelligence). To be performed by the PhD Student. (approx. 15mins). To assess determine whether their intelligence level is above normal.
1.
Data analysis The data analysis will be performed on all the outcome measures. i. Looking for differences in the scores of each of the aforementioned tests between groups (Groups A, B, C and D): We will use a mixed model Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) with between subjects factors (group - comparing all 4 groups) and within subjects factors (time - pre, mid and post intervention).
ii. We will assess whether behavioural outcome measures correlate with other measures of communication (as measured by the CHAPS and CCC2 questionnaires and from the SIFTER and LIFE-R and APHAB questionnaires). We will use regression analysis to measure this.
Other issues None of these tests are invasive or unpleasant, and they are conducted in comfortable sound levels (slightly higher than the usual conversational level). Any additional information on the children that might emerge during the study will be reported back to the clinician at the APD clinic to inform the child's management.
All children who participate will receive a book voucher of GBP10 at the end of each test session. Travel expenses will also be reimbursed (up to GBP10).
